frameDefinitions: Temporary or permanent Styles and Configurations of Hair, as well as its inherent Nature.
An Agent performs an Action incorrectly.
An Agent has committed a Wrong in the past and is making Amends for it.
The words of this frame describe how a Resource_controller spends money or other Resources for a particular purpose .
An Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an Offender who participated in an Crime.
The words in this frame describe the process of making amends for some (wrongful) action (the Injury) committed by the Wrongdoer.
frameExamples: On either side her head gleamed coiled <t>braids</t> of dark-gold hair , almost pale copper in the subdued light of the room .
He <t>atoned</t> for his sin with good works.

A Fort Worth man convicted of a robbery his brother later confessed
to committing was granted <t>clemency</t> on December 20, 2002, by Governor Rick Perry.
listRoleDefinitions: This role is the hair itself
This role is the Possessor of the body part.
Temporary Configurations of hair (eg braid, bun, ponytail).   Something done to the hair merely by movement.
A property of the hair (eg curly, fine, brown).  This acts much like 'Descriptor' in the Observable_bodyparts Frame.  Colors, styles, natural properties are described by this frame element.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs an action incorrectly.
<fen>Patient</fen> is the entity affected by the <fen>Agent</fen>'s bungling of an <fen>Action</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Action</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs incorrectly.
The type of action that the <fen>Agent</fen> habitually bungles.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the bungling occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the bungling occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> has committed a <fen>Wrong</fen> and is making <fen>Amends</fen>.
<fen>Wrong</fen> identifies the act committed by the <fen>Agent</fen> for which <fen>Amends</fen> are made.
<fen>Amends</fen> marks expressions that indicate what the <fen>Agent</fen> does to compensate for the <fen>Wrong</fen> that was committed.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> atones for the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> expiates the <fen>Wrong</fen>.

The <fen>Resource_controller</fen> is the individual whose frugality or generosity is being described. Person typically occurs as the External Argument or, in some cases when <fen>Behavior</fen> is also expressed, in an <ment>of</ment>-PP:
Some specific <fen>Behavior</fen> may be described as frugal or extravagant, rather than attributing the characteristic directly to the <fen>Resource_controller</fen>.
This role is the resource which the <fen>Resource_controller</fen> expends.
The individual who is accused or convicted of a <fen>Crime</fen>.
An action deemed criminal by law.
The constitutionally specified authority who has the power to grant clemency.
The time at which clemency is granted.
The location at which the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> grants clemency.
The <fen>Injured_party</fen> was affected by some previous wrongful act of the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> and who should benefit from the reparations.
The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action that  the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> committed against the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.  Although conceptually present, this role need not always be realized.
The <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends to the <fen>Injured_party</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Benefiting_action</fen> is performed by the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> to make amends.
<fen>Gift</fen> identifies the entity that the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> gives to the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when amends are made.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends.
listRoleExamples: Her <fex><t>tresses</t></fex> were golden.
<fex>Michael's</fex> hair is long.
I pulled Michael's  <fex>ponytail</fex>.
<fex>Mickey</fex> botched that swing.
Mickey fumbled <fex>the ball</fex>.
Mickey botched <fex>that swing</fex>.
The Austro-Hungarian Empire had a long history of <fex>military</fex> screw-ups.
<fex>Syria</fex> has atoned for its support of Iraq.
Smithers is atoning <fex>for his misspent youth</fex>.
He atoned for his sin <fex>with good works</fex>.
<fex>Jo</fex> is very frugal.
It's thrifty of Jo <fex>to re-use teabags</fex>.
Pat is wasteful <fex>with her time</fex>.

Since 1976, <fex>225 death row inmates</fex> have been granted clemency for humanitarian
reasons.
I never saw a legal case where a person was given clemency <fex>for murder</fex>.
Mr. Papa was granted clemency for a drug conviction <fex>by Mr. Pataki</fex>, and released in 1997

In addition to Ms.  White, 55, Mr.  Pataki granted clemency <fex>yesterday</fex> to three men serving long prison terms for offenses under the stern Rockefeller-era drug laws that mandate long sentences for some relatively low-level drug crimes.
Apparently, no woman has ever been granted clemency <fex>there</fex>.
You can never make amends <fex>to Susan</fex> for standing her up.
Wyelander sought reparations <fex>for the brutal murder of his nephew</fex>.
How  can <fex>I</fex> make it up to you?
Between friends, amends can be made <fex>by apologizing</fex>.
He made it up to her <fex>with a bouquet of flowers</fex>.
He made amends to her <fex>that very afternoon</fex>.
Restitution was given <fex>in Milan</fex> with the Treaty of Abiselle.
